div.head: GREECE AND TURKEY.
div.p: A Vienna newspaper bra published a story which it has received from Sofia, to the effect that the Minuter of Greece at Constantinople has had instructions to propose to the Sultan an offensive and defensive alliance with Turkey. The suggestion is that Turkey should declare war on Bulgaria and invade Eastern Roumelia, while the Greek and Turkish fleet should toge her attack the Bulgarian ports in the Black Sea. The story even goes so far as to say that the indemnisy to be demanded by the allies will be twenty millions sterling. It is difficult to understand, remarks the “Globe,” how a paper of any standing could seriously publish such a ridiculous invention unless it intended to envenom a situation which it already sufficiently strained. The relations between Bulgaria and Greece are such that the publication of this “canard” in a Viennese paper may very well inflame the ignorant Bulgars to a dangerous degree, for it will be sent all over the Principality as the informaion of a European paper, and therefore authentic. Such an alliance would be quite impossible, if for no other reason than that Greece has not yet forgotten the disastrous war of 1897, and that while Crete is separated from the Kingdom, there will always be a subject of dispute with Turkey Besides, the Powers would justifiably interfere at once, and Greece would destroy the sympathy that is still felt for her in Europe. The story is merely another move in the campaign of calumny which has been so cleverly worked for the last year or two against Greece from Sofia, and will deceive none but those who wish to be deceived. There has been an increasing output of these stories of late, their authors trusting that the cumulative effect of them will be to discredit Greece in the eyes of Europe.

div.head: IRISH DISLOYALTY.
div.p: UNION JACK INSULTED.
Dublin, September 25.
At the opening of the Main Drainage system an alderman oat off the Union Jack which was flying on the steamer on which the officials were gathered.
Several members of the Corporation left the luncheon during the toast in honour of the King.

Mr. Redmond, speaking at Grange, complained that the Government had repeatedly falsified its promises. The Irish party would accept no makeshift but nothing short of a complete measure of Home Role. The Government was not sufficiently strong to govern Ireland against the wish of the people. (R.)
London, September 25.

The “Standard" states that in spite of Mr. Redmond’s assurances there is a tacit and definite understanding between the Nationalists and the Government whose offer is expectedly generous. Mr. Redmond is depreciating the gift in order to escape the disagreeable necessity of expressing his gratitude to the English administration. (Reuter)

div.head: RIOTING IN ATLANTA.
div.p: New York, September .

Rioting was resumed in Atlanta on Sonday night. A negro was killed. The troops called out and quelled the disturbances. Altogether 12 negroes and 2 white men have been killed and many wounded. (Reuter)
London, September 26.

The details of the massacre at Atlanta published throughout America resemble the descriptions of a uossian massacre. The northern Press declared that the outbreak was fanned by Atlanta newspapers, one of which offered £200 reward for killing every negro charged with outraging white women. (R.)
New York, September 25.

Rioting contionues in Atlanta. Four more negroes have been killed. Many persons have been arrested in possession of arms. The negro population is panic stricken in view of the determination shown by the mounted police to avenge the murder of the police officer. (Reuter)

div.head: DUMA VICE-PRESIDENT.
div.p: OSTRACIZED BY KURSK NOBILITY.
St. PETERSBURG, September 25. The Kursk nobility have ostracized Prince Dolgorokoff ex Vice-President of the Duma, on account of his having signed the Viborg manifesto. (Reuter)

div.head: THE PASSAGE OF HERTZIAN WAVES.
div.p: Ghent, September 25.

The Institute of International Law discussed regulations regarding aeronautics and wireless telegraphy, and adopted articles declaring that the air should be free but that each state should have the faculty with a view to its own safety, to oppose the passage of hertzian waves through its territory. (Reuter)

div.head: PRINCE GEORGE’S FAREWELL.
div.p: Canea, September 25.
Prince George has left the island after an impassioned farewell.

In a proclamation to the islanders he urged them to continue to gain the favour of the Powers and to place confidence in M. Zaimis in order to obtain the surest and most expeditions fulfilment of the national wishes. He prayed that before long Crete might form an inseparable part of the motherland. (Reuter)
Athens September 25.
Prince George has left Crete. M. Zaimis, his successor, will leave next week. (Havas)

div.head: CHINESE IN THE TRANSVAAL.
div.p: JOHANNESBURG, September 25.
Fourteen Chinese attacked the house of the captain of the New Heriot mine. The captain was killed as well as another white man and two others were wounded. Seven Chinese have men arrested. (Reuter)

div.head: TROUBLE IN BENIN.
div.p: Lagos. September 25.

Trouble has arisen in Benin City. The traders have fled. It is reported that two Europeans have been killed. Telegraphic communication has been interrupted. Reinforcements have been sent up-country. (Reuter)

div.head: THE BRUNSWICK DIET.
div.p: Berlin, September 25.
The Brunswick Diet has deferred taking measures for the election of a regent in the hope that an arrangement will be effected by be Emperor with the Duke of Cumberland. (Reuter)

div.head: MR CHAMBERLAIN’S ILLNESS.
div.p: London, September 25.
Acting on the doctor's advice Mr. Chamberlain has cancelled all his engagements for the Autumn. (Reuter)

div.head: EMPEROR JOSEPH ILL.
div.p: Paris, September 25.
It is reported that the Emperor Franic Joseph is seriously ill (Raw)

div.head: THE SULTAN’S ILLNESS.
div.p: Paris, September 25.
The news that the Sultan is suffering from cancer is unfounded. (Havas)

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, le 25 Septembre. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres se maintient à 4 1/2 pour cent. Hier, au Scock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est demeuré inchangé à 86 3/8, de même que l'Unifiée à 104 1/2. La National Bank a perdu 1/8 à 9 7/8 et la D ï-a autant à 16 3/4. L'Agricole a gagné 1/8 à 9 7/8. La Delta Light a cloturé à son prix précédent, soit 11 1/2.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien et la Banque d’Athènes sont restées stationnaires à 778 et 144.

Ce matin, notre marché des s’est montré moins timoré qu'hier, bien qu'il ne se soit produit aucun changement favorable dans la situation monétaire eu Occident. Certes, la Bourse reste indécise, et les cours pratiqués dénotent toujours une certaine tendance à la réalisation, ou bien des velléités de spéculation à découvert. Mais il est visible qu'une grossi baisse rencontrerait des obstacles preaque insurmontables par suite même des cours avantageux qu'elle déterminerait à la veille de la reprise des affaires. On ne saurait, eu effst, perdre de vue que les prix actuels sont déjà attrayants pour les achats sérieux, pour les placements; en outre, le découvert contribuerait puissamment, s’il s’acceutuait, à amener une reprise rapide.

La National Bank a c’ôturé à 26 3/8 et l'Agricole à 9 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto s'est alourdie à 222-223, la Banque d'Athènes à 142-143 et la Banque d'Orient à 130. La Banque d'Abyssinie a été offerteà 5 1/2.

L'action Crédit Foncier a débuté à 772 1/2 pour avancer en ôturé à 776-777; l’obligation à lots ancienne a progressé à 337-338. La Dura a faibli à 16 13/16. La Béhéra a gagné 1/8 à 36 1/4. La Nile Land a clôturé à 14 7/16, vendeurs.

L'action Immobilière a reculé à 386 et la part de fondateur à 730. En bonne tendance. l'action Agricole du Nil a passé de 260 à 272 273; la part de fondateur a gagné 5/8 à 8 8 1/16. L'action Enterprise and Development a été ramenée à 12 1/2 et la part de fondateur à 21 3/4. Les Improvemènts ont réactionné à 5 1/4 5/16. Lis Entreprises Immobilières et de Travaux ont été échangées à 4 1/4.
La Delta Light s'est raffermie à 11 13/16 Las Jouissances Eaux da Caire sont revenues à 266. Les Ciments ont avancé à 70.
Daus le groupe des valeurs hoteliè es les Nungovich ont été délaissés à 17 1/16. Les Egyptien ont fléchi à 6 1/8 et les Upper Egypt à 4 9/16 5/8. Les National ont perdu 7/32 à 3 9/16 5/8.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Hooker ont été traités entre O 15/16 et £1. Las Nile Cold Storage ont été recherchés à O 5/3 11/16. Les Sait and Soda se sont inscrits à 21 sh. et les Markets à 25 sb. 3. La Khédivial Mail a rétrogradé à 3 1/2 sh. et les Cotton Mills à 5 sh. 9.
A l'assemblée générale ordinaire de l’Egyptien Land and General Trust Ltd. (Hooke ), qui s'est tenue à Londres le 14 Septembre, le rapport du conseil et les comptes et bilan ont été approuvés.
La nomination de M.E. Toriel comme administrateur a été co: firmée.

Dans son discours, le président de l'assemblée a déclaré qu'il eût été agréable de distribuer un bon dividende pour le premier exercice, en réalisant les achats de terrains faits par la Société ; mais le conseil d'administration a jugé préférable d’attendre que ces propriétés aient acquis la plus grande-value possible afin d'en faire profiter pleinement les actionnaires.

Les journaux de Londres annoncent qu’un accord vient d'être conclu entre les producteurs de sel en Angleterre. Cette entente, qui a pour objet de relever les prix du sel aux Indes, est. appelée à favoriser indirectement la Port-Saïd Sait Association, qui exporte dans ces pays.

Carnet de l’actionnaire. Il est porté à la connaissance des action naires de la Société anonyme des Grands Garages d'Egypte que le 1er versement de L.E. 1 per action sera payable le 1er Octobre prochain. Les paiements doivent être effectués b l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank, au Caire.

- Les actionnaires de la Gharbieh Land Co. sont invités à effectuer le versement du Sème quart, soit LE 1 par action, le 30 Septembre courant, an siège delà Société au Caire, ou à l’Anglo Egyptien Bank.

- Les actionnaires de la Khédivial Mail Co. sont informés que le coupon No. 16 des notions au porteur privilégiées cumulatives de 5 1/2 pour cent sera payé à partir du 1er Octobre prochain à la Banque Impériale Ottomane à Alexandrie. Les propriétaires des actions nominatives recevront leurs "dividend warranta” par la poste.

- Les actionnaires de l’Egyptian Auto Transport Co. sont invités à faire le 3ème versement, soit P.E. 125 par action, à partir du 1er jusqu’au 15 Octobre prochain. Les paiements devront être effectués à la Cassa di Sconto, à Alexandrie et au Caire.
Las recettes de la Delta Light Railways pour la semaine au 15 Septembre courant es sont chiffées par L.E. 4,160 contre 3,784 en 1905, soit en augmentation de L.E. 426.
Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Avril 1906 ont atteint L.E. 93,552 contre 85,963 en 1905, soit en plus-value de L.E. 7,589 pour l'exercice courant.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd’hui à midi et demie.)
Soit par suite de la baissé du taux privé d’escompte à 4 3/8 soit en raison de la demande locale, il y a aujourd’hui reprise presque générale sur notre marché.
La National Bank est particulièrement favorisée. Elle regagne à 26 9/16 les 3/16 qu'elle avait perdus.
La La Deïra Smith remonte à 16 7/8, la Cassa di Sconto à 222 1/4 et 216 1/4, la Delta Land à 3 5/16, la Nile Land à 14 9/16.
De 25 les Sucreries s’avancent à 26 francs, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 34/- à 34/3 et le Comptoir nouvelle émission de 6 3/16 à 6 7/32.
L'Union Foncière est de pins en plus recher chée à 6 livres.
Eu revanche, les Tramways d'Alexandrie fléchissent, la Privilégiée de 188 à 187, la Dividende de 343 à 339, la Banque d'Athènes de 143 3/4 à 143 1/4 et la Land Bank de 8 29/32 à 8 7/8.
La Banque d'Orient est complètement délaistée à 130.

div.p: Eighteenth 6 1/2% Cumulative Prererence Dividend.

Notice is hereby given to holders of Bearer Warrants that Interest Coupon No. 14 of the above issue, due on the 1st day of October, 1906, will be payable (less income tax) on and after that date at the Bankers of the Company, the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Limited, 87 Clements Lane, London, E.C.

Coupons must be left at the London Office of the Company, 65, London Wall, London, E.C., three clear days, for examination previous to payment and to be entered in numerical lists which may be obtained at the Head Office, London, or from the Office of the Company in Cairo, upon application. Foreign and Provincial holders must forward Coupon through their Bankers for collection as they will not be paid through the post.
By order on the Board.

div.head: Direction Generale des Postes
div.p: L'administration des Postes met en adjudi cation l'entreprise des transports postaux dans la ville du Caire aux créditions stipulées dans le cahier des charges déposé auprès de cette Direction Générale (Bureau de Secrétariat) et à la Direction Locale des Postes du Caire.

Les demandes devront être adressées à S.E. le Directeur Général des Poètes à Alexandrie. sur papier timbré de P.T. 3 et sous double enveloppe, celle in'érieure portant la mention ‘Offre pour transports postaux dans la ville Caire;” el'ew seront reçues jusqu'au S1 Octobre prochain inclusivement.
L'administration ne s'engage pas à accepter l’offre la plus basse ni à donner suite à l’adjudication.
Avis Important

Mess. Rizzo & Co, éditeurs-propriétaires de l’Egyptian Directory (l’Annuaive Egyptien) tiennent à mettre le Public en garde contre les agissements de certaines personnes qui sollicitent et se font remettre d’avencé de l’argent pour insertions et announces dans des publications qualifiées' de différenta titres et qui n'ont jamais vu le jour.

Afiu d’éviter toutes confusions et surprises Mess. Rizzo & Co informant le Publioc d’Alexandrie que toutes insertions et annoncés dans l’Egyptian Directory doivent être remises à leurs Agents, Mess. Fern. Gallois Co, et sont payables après apparition du volume:

Grâce à la collaboration de leurs nombreux Agents, Mess. Rizzo & Co ont apporté d'importantes modifications et rectifications à leur édition 1907, qui paraîtra en Janvier prochain, et ils se flattent de présenter au Public un ouvrage toujours plus complet, plus correct et plut intéressant.

Les personnes qui auraient des changements d'adreésse à notifiér, sont priéss de les trammettre sans retard directement au Caire aux bureaux de l'Administiation Centrale "The Egyptien Directory" Sharia Kaer-el-Nil. 28,566 3-1

Hedjaz Railway.
The Turkish S.S. Namoussa, which has armed at Port Said, has a large cargo of material for the Hedjaz Railway.
Bathing Fatality.
On Monday a native of Cairo was drowned in the Nile, near Kubri-El-Aama where he was bathing. The body has now yet been discovered.
The Brindisi Mall.
Owing to the late arrival of the Brindisi boat at Port Said the mail will not be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, until nine o’clock this evening.
Bubonic Plague
A native of the Menshieh quarter of Alexandria waa found dead yesterday afternoon. Two new admissions to hospital are reported from Suez and one death at that port.
Alhambra Theatre.

The management of the Alhambra Theatre Alexandria, announce the arrival of a Turkish, comedy and vaudeville troupe, which will give their first representation on Saturday under the direction of Mr. Benlian.
A Moslem Fanatlo

A student who used to intone the Koran at a butcher's shop in the Moharrem Bey quarter, yesterday evening, after singing some ayets took one of the batcher's knifes and stabbed himself, because the butcher refused to give him the fee due to him for intoning the Koran.
Buried Alive

While two native workmen were digging in a pit at Mex yesterday, they were buried under a heavy mass of earth which fell on them. They were rescued alive, but one of them succumbed a few hours afterwards to the injuries, which he had sustained. The other was only slightly injured.
Government Staff Commission

Lord Edward Cecil's Commission is to meet twice next week. It is not known how long the Commission will continue for, but it has been decided the new scheme will come into force with the new year. Mr. Dunlop has requested to retire from the Commission, as he has numerous other duties to fulfil, and he has appointed in his place Mr. Sharman, Director of the Saiieh School.
Port Said Institutions

The new National Bank building at Port Said is fast approaching completion, and the old and new English Clubs, which have combined, should be installed in their new premises over the bank by the end of the year. With regard to the sports club, a fine pavilion, three tennis courts, and cricket pitch are already completed and it is expected that the new grounds of the club will be formally opened very shortly.
New Carman steamship Line.

The number of German ships passing through the Suez Canal will soon be largely increased. Reliable reports in shipping circles state that a movement is maturing to offer strong opposition to the Hamburg American Line in its trade with East Asia. A combination of merchants in Hamburg and London intend to establish a regular service between Hamburg and East Asia, to consist of fifteen large steamships.
The Judicial Languages

One knows that lately English has been added as a judicial language to French, Italian, and Arabic. Already a rather large number of procedure cases have been presented in the new language. The Berlitz Schools (Cairo, No 1, Sharia Kamel; Alexandria, No. 12, rue Rosette) will quickly allow all those who frequent the Palace to acquire a knowledge of English, or of any of the other languages Trial lessons are given free.
Schism In Jewry.

The Grand Rabbi has at last restored pesos in the distracted Jewish Colony of Cairo, and, following his advice, the members of the provisional committee have resigned until his Beatitude gives his final decision, a decision upon which the regular working of the Community's affairs depends. Alone the Grand Rabbi can legally put a end to a state of things wherein important social questions are sacrificed to personal considerations.
A Coptic Quarrel.

Last Monday Kirillus Hanna, a Cairo Copt, and his wife were stabbed by a cousin of the latter, who was dining with Kirillus. It appears that Kirillus objected to his wife appearing and closed the door of the room in which she was seated, there being a communication with the dining-room. Girgis Hanna, his guest, expressed his disapproval, and a quarrel ensued in which both Kirillus and the woman, who had come to her husband’s assistance were stabbed. The police arrived on the scene and arrested Girgis and the other two parties were removed to hospital.
New Employment Registry.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria [Advt.]

div.head: NATIONALIST AGITATION.
div.p: DEBATING SOCIETIES IN CAIRO.

A significant and somewhat disturbing portent is the number of debating societies, which have arisen in Cairo, where most violent speeches are habitually indulged in against the British Occupation of Egypt. The members of these societies are principally recruited from the Egyptian Government schools, such as the Kbedivial Law School and similar institutions. The pupils of these schools are encouraged to speak and as the Arab is generally a fluent orator, these sort of meetings are much relished. We understand that these societies are increasing in number, and as they grow stronger, the virulence of the politics indulged in appears to become more and more marked. Some years ago a debating society was founded at the Khedivial School of Law for the purpose of discussing moot points of jurisprudence. The founder was Mr., now Judge, She'don Amos, and we remember at the time noting the fact that the late M. Testoud, the regretted principal of the School, was opposed to the project on the grounds that it might lead to seditious purposes. His advice, however, was not hearkened to, with the deplorable results which we are now witnessing.

div.head: THE ASSYR MUTINY.
div.p: News comes from Ismailieh that four of the Syrian mutineers escaped from the transport S.S. Coswa by the East bank of the Canal, They are being actively sought for by tie coastguards of that district.

div.head: MAILS FOR AUSTRALIA.
div.p: It is rumoured that the new steamship combine, which secured the Australian mail contract, has fallen through owing to the fact that the promoters could not comply with the regulations of the Federal Government regarding the pay of the sailors.

div.head: MILITARY SCHOOL.
div.p: The Ministry of War has given notion that the scholars who desire to enrol themselves at the Military School must hold the elementary education certificate.

div.head: THE GEM CUTTER’S CRAFT.
div.p: Mr. Leopold Claremont, who is known to our readers as the author of “A Tabular Arrangement of the Distinguishing Characteristics and Localities of Precious Stones, has just completed a work entitled "The Gem Cutter’s Craft" Although there are many books upon the subject, this is the first to be written by a practical gem cutter. To all who are in any way interacted in precious stones, this work should be of great value. It contains upward of 100 illustrations of rough gems, mines, methods of scouring and discriminating gems, the details of the process of cutting diamonds and other precious stones, etc. This book will shortly be published by Messrs. G. Bell & Sons, London.

EGYPT EXPLORATION FUND.
EGYPT AND GREECE-

The late exhibition ff the Egypt Exploration Fund at King’s College was distinguished from those of earlier year by a series of lectores illustrated by lantern-slides, the three lecturers being Dr. Neville, Mr. H. R. Hall, and Mr. Currelly. Dr. Neville's discourse was in effect a description of the work at Deir el-Bahari; but Mr. Hall gave a very interesting account of the connexion between early Greece and Egypt—a connexion which he asserted to be proved so far as Twelfth Dynasty times are concerned and to be very probable for neolithic ones. His idea, which he broached last year in "The Journal for Hellenic Studies,” is that the earliest civilisation of both countrieas was neither Semitic nor Aryan, but was derived from Prof Sergi's Mediterranean race of whom be considers the "dark dolichocephalic” Southern European of the present day the representative. He pointed out many likenesses between the Eleventh Dynasty temple at Deir el-Bahari, the Labyrinth at Hawara, and the Cretan Labyrinth at Cnossus; while he concluded that such differences as do occur can be accounted for by the contrast between the ever-varying beauty of the Greek landscape and the flat monotony of the Nile Valley.
SMYRNA-AIDIN RAILWAY.

Sir Nicholas O’Connor is to be congratulated on the diplomatic victory which he has just completed by securing the Porte’s confirmation of the convention with the Aidin Railway Company. The convention, which has long been pending, has (the “Standard" says) been a matter of considerable oontention, the Germans watching every point most jealously in the interests of the Baghdad railway and each concession won represents a score for the British Ambassador.

The convention provides for the prolongation of the Aidin railway to Lake Egerdir, with a branch to Budur, and, at the same time, it extends the period of the concession for sixteen years. An undertaking is given by the Porte that no concession shall be given for the construction of a line from Adalis, either towards Baghdad or the Anatolian lines. This undertaking will be of considerable value.
The Smyrna Aidin railway,which was started 5O years ago, is already 550 kilometres in length, and has been the source of Smyrna’s development and prosperity.
OBITUARY.
MRS. GOAR.

We regret to announce the death of Mrs. Sarins Goar, wife of that respected and well- known member of the Jewish Community of Alexandria, Mr Joseph Gear. Mrs. Goar died at 4 o’clock this morning at her residence in Avenue Porte Rosette, Alexandria. She was 54 years of age. The funeral cortege will leave the house at 4 o’clock this afternoon. We beg to tender our sincere sympathy to the deceased, husband, Mr. Joseph Goer, and to Mr. and Mrs. Edin Goar.
DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
(Communication Officielle)
La Délégation Municipale s’est réunie le 25 Septembre 1906 à 5 h. p.m. tons la présidence de S.E. le Dr. Schiess Pacba.
Présents MM. J. Barbaza, Mansour Bey Youssef, A. Ralli et G. Zervudachi, membres, 1. Sedky Bey, secrétaire.
La Délégation décide, conformément à une demande du Gouvernorat, l'installation de 3 lanternes à gaz dans la rue Ali Bey el Kébir.

Le contrat de concession des travaux d'asphaltage de trottoirs confiés à la maison Cugini Praga, expirant le 31 décembre 1906, la Délégation décide de provoquer des offres poor la mise en adjudication de ces travaux pour une nouvelle période de trois années allant jusqu’au 31 décembre 1909.

Communication est donnée d’une lettre du 31 Septembre 1906 du Président du Conseil Municipal de Londres proposant la eandidature de Mr. Lloyd Davier, actuellement chef adjoint de l'Ingénieur en chef de la ville de Birmingham, au porte d'ingénieur en chef de de la Municipalité d'Alexandrie.
Cette candidature sera soumise à la Commission Municipale à la date fixée pour le concours au dit poste.
La Délégation prend connaissance d'une lettre de l'Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat faisant des propositions pour le balayage des plateformes et routes do Gabbary.
Elle décide de répondre en faissut connselure à la dite administration les conditions auxquelles elle serait disposés à faire effectuer ce balayage par les soins de la Municipalité.
Le séance est levés à 6 h. 1/2 p.m.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ.
div.p: ENGLISHMAN ARRESTED.
(FROM OUR SUEZ CORRESPONDENT. )
Suez, Tuesday.

Mr. Francis Seaton, a passenger on board R.M.S. Omrah from Australia, was arrested yesterday morning on the steamer's arrival at Suez by the British Consular authorities here on a provisional warrant issued by H.B.M’s Consul at Port Said.
Arrival of the Assyr.
The Turkish transports Assyr and Coswa came out of the Canal yesterday evening at 6.30 accompanied by the British cruiser Proserpine, apparently owing to the recent troubles in Port Said.

During the passage in the Canal the Proserpine was constantly placed between the two transports, in a way that she could closely watch their movements. Shortly after their arrival at Suez, the troopships sailed for Hodeidah, followed by the British cruiser.
The Caledonia Still Asdhore.
The position of the S.S. Caledonia ashore in the Canal since Saturday last is still unchanged. Renewed efforts to refloat her have been unsuccessful.

div.head: PORT SAID AND COMMERCE.
div.p: (From a Port Said Correspondent.) From time to time one hears of efforts to develop Port Said as a commercial centre for Egyptian trade and more especially for the export of Egypt's chief product, cotton. So far, however, there has been little evidence in this respect to justify the idea that Port Said will ever become a formidable rival to Alexandria, the great centre of the commercial life of Egypt. Although the vast extensions at present being carried out will still farther improve what is already a very fine harbour, the immediate intention is merely to further facilitate the transit traffic. In the course of a year little short of four thousand steamers pass through the Suez Canal going and coming from the Far East. In addition another five hundred steamers make Port Said a port of call either carrying passengers, general cargo, or ceal. Excellent hotel accommodation has been made for those who elect to stay over night in the town.

Although the place itself offers little attraction to visitors, there are few passengers who do not avail themselves of the opportunity of a ran ashore. Quite a large business is done with these, more especially in cigarettes, Eastern curios, newspapers, periodicals, and the ubiquitous pictorial postcards. Owing to the great improvement and acceleration of the railway service it is now possible for visitors and tourists to reach Cairo within five hours of stepping ashore at Port Said. All the great shipping lines who cater for the passenger service act as feeders during the season to the various tourist combinations who all have agents at Port Said.

The only substance at present exported to any extent from Port Said is salt. The Port Said Salt Association has shown commendable energy in developing a large and increasing trade, more especially with Calcutta. It is hoped, however, that the development of the Menzaleh Canal will increase the trade with the interior, although it is unlikely that much of any of the present export trade will be deflected from Alexandria. Port Said can boast of a considerable fishing fleet which plies its calling on Lake Menzaleh and the coast. The manufacture and export of cigarettes from this centre has also assumed considerable proportions. But for the most part the community depends almost entirely on the employment given by the Suez Canal Company and the numerous shipping firms.

Anyone returning at the present time to Port Said after an absence of some years is at once struck with the great strides which have been made in the development of the town of late years. The leading Egyptian banks—no small number—have either already erected or are in the course of erecting imposing edifices, standing monuments either to the present prosperity of the town or promising marks of its future possibilities. Although therein not exactly a house (amine, good residences are at a premium, the constant raising of rents showing that the proportion of demand to supply justifies further speculation in building. Do the whole the future of Port Said seems to justify a bright forecast inextricably associated as it is with the fortunes of the Suez Canal Company. At the same time it is never likely to become a serious competitor to Alexandria as a centre for the Egyptian export trade.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Seti left Malta on Monday afternoon, and is due here to-morrow afternoon with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Russian Steam Navigation Company's mail-boat Reine Olga will leave Alexandria at 3 p m. on Tuesday for Pirseus, Dardanelles, Constantinople, and Odessa.
The Russian Steam Navigation Company's mail boat Rossia will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Saturday for Port Said, Jaffa, Beyrout, Tripoli, Chie, Smyrna, Dardanelles, Constantinople, and Odessa.
The Khedivial mail steamship Prince Abbas will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Saturday and Port Said at 4 p. m. on Sunday for Beyrout, Tripoli, Mersina, Alexandretta, Larnaca, Caiffa, and Jaffa.

div.head: LUCKNOW DAY.
div.p: MILITARY SPORTS AT MUSTAPHA.

A glorious record is that of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers or, as they were known in old Indite times, the 102nd Royal Madras Fusiliers, the First Madras Fusiliers, and the Madras European Regiment. They have seen service wherever it was to be had, and did splendidly in the South African War, but the military event with which their name will ever be associated was the part they took in the relief of Lucknow, on September 25, 1857, of which yesterday was the anniversary. A few notes on that memorable advance of General Havelock will be of interest to all.

On May 10, 1857 the news of the outbreak and the mutiny in Bengal reached Madras and by the 19th of the same month 917 men sailed from that port reaching Calcutta on the 23rd. They were sent at once up country to Benares and Allahabad in detachments; some by the Grand Trunk Road and others by river. Benares was reached on June 8, and on the 4th the regiment had its first encounter with the rebels. Disarming the native troops Neill pushed rapidly on to Allahabad, where by June 16 the greater portion of the regiment had arrived, and restored order.

On the 30th June 200 of the rank and file under Major Renaud advanced on Cawnpore followed on the 3rd July by 100 under Major Spurgeon and on the 4th by 200 under Major Stephenson, joining General Havelock's column. Neill remained behind at Allahabad. On the 6th July Spurgeon's detachment repulsed the enemy on the left bank of the Ganges. On the 15th July were fought the notions of Aoury and Pundos Muddee, Major Renaud being wounded.

On the 16th the battle of Cawnpore was fought, and Neill left Allahabad for that city. On the 21st Major Renaud died and Major Stephenson assumed command of the Regiment Havelock crossed the Ganges on the 26th into Oude for the relief of Lucknow, leaving Neill in command at Cawnpore. On the 24th, the final push to Lucknow was made. The crux of the position was Char Bagh Bridge, which was heavily fortified with cannon, and flanked by houses fall of rifle men. This was stormed by part of the Regiment led by Capt. Grant; an action in which Lieut. Havelock, who showed such bravery gained the V.C.

The sports which were held at Mustapha Barracks yesterday and Monday were very successful. The sandy soil prevented any records being broken, for spiked boots were absolutely useless.—Private Evans was certainly the hero of the day : considering how heavily handicapped he was, and that he had run all Monday, he did wonderfully well in yesterday’s finals. Private Rice, who won the shot-put, was the winner of the shot-put prize of 1897 at Aldershot. Not only was he successful at the sports, but he and Private Evans did a fair share of the work in connection with preparing the ground for the day's events.
It was a matter of universal regret that the each looked forward-to mile race between Corporal Wilson and Sergeant Denyer did not come off, owing to unavoidable circumstances.

Mrs Pilson, the charming wife of the gallant major who won his Brevet rank in Matabele and, awarded the prises after which Colonel Chapman, the popular commanding officer, in a few choice words congratulated the Fusiliere on the great success of the day, assured them if the continued sympathy and support which could be shown them in their sports by their officers, and paid a warm tribute to the labours if the committee, specially mentioning Major Downing, the president. During the sports the Egyptian Cavalry band played an excellent election of music in remarkably creditable time and tone. The following are the results of the various events:—

div.head: B.R.C. ALEXANDRIA !
div.p: In our report of the British Rifle Club’s (Alexandria) shooting competitions of last Saturday which appeared in our issue of yesterday we omitted to mention Mr. W. G. Jacob as winner of the “range” prize at 600 yards.
It has been decided that on and after the 13th prox. the order of shooting will be 600,800, and 200 yards.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Ei Ferik Husni Pasha has been appointed Mihmandar to H.H. the Khedive daring the latter's stay at Constantinople.
It is reported that the Khedivah-Mother will pass next winter at Constantinople, and will postpone her visit to Mecca until the following year.
Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, President of the Council of Ministers, is expected to arrive from Europe on the 17th prox.
This morning, Mustapba Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria, paid an official visit to Mr. Hewat, United State Consul.
H.I.M. the Sultan has conferred the Medjidieh of the 1st class, set in brilliants, on Dr. Bergmann; and the Osmanieh of the 1st class on his assistant, Dr. Bier.
Comanos Pasha arrived yesterday at Alexandria on his return from Europe by the Messageries Maritimes steamer.
Dr. Ruffer, C.M.G., President of the Quarantine Board, who has been attending the annual congress of the British Medical Association at Toronto, Canada, returned to Alexandria, via Port Said, to-day.
Count Bernsdoff, the newly appointed German Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General is expected at Cairo on November 10.
Dr. Morrison is at present attending the Quarter Centenary celebrations of Aberdeen University, of which he is a distinguished graduate.
Mr. Victor G. Shilston, managing director of the Nile Flotilla Company, arrived yesterday from England by the P. & 0. Mooltan.
A marriage has been arranged between M. Pietro Sappari, of Florence, and Mile Marie Haicalis, sister of the proprietor of the "Phare d’Alexandrie.”

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.
OFFICIALS AND CIVILIANS.

To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette.” Sir,I have been more than amused at the controversy which has been going on in your valuable paper, under the above heading, and especially the latter in your issue of the 22nd inst.

The idea conveyed to one’s mind is, that the official is not a civilian, until one begins to consider the subject, and I for that one do not hesitate to assert that the writer of the letter above quoted is entirely at fault in his remark on the “unofficial class, who like to pose for what they are not," as it is an undeniable fact, that it is the official who tries his utmost upon all occasions to ape and rub arms against the British Officer. Sometimes he contrives to manage his point, but it is only then under kind condescension and sufferance.

I am certain that if some of the officials that I have seen were to assume the tarbush, they would never look like British Officers, under that or any other condition, and would possibly have to take a back Seat, even in "the common herd of commercial people!”

It must be left to your readers to judge whether that sentence is in good taste or an undeserved insult to a multitude of respectable people whose sad failing appears to be that they are not officials.

Possibly the writer wishes us to imagine the is some person of note, who knows well the subject he is discussing. I would infer from his style of writing that probably he had received a fairly good school board education, but that he does not possess that essence of a gentleman termed refinement.
I would assume, moreover, that he is an official who would evidently have been entirely out of place in the commercial world, had he have tried his luck in it.

When will the officials grasp the fact that they are the well paid servants of the public. And that it is their bounden duty not only to treat all classes, even the ‘common herd’ with courtesy and respect, but upon the playing of the Khedivial anthem and "God save the King" to stand and take off their hats and thereby set the example to those who may not do so.
I quite see that if the tarbush was worn, it would be a splendid opportunity for the officials to again copy and pretend to be the British Officer, by saluting in military fashion.
Furthermore, as there are so many English men in Egypt, who “pose for what they are not," why should the Levantine not follow their lead and do likewise.
Example is better than precept
Another 20 years’s resident, but not an official
Cairo, September 23.
WANTED: A CARACOL.

To the Editor of the “Egyptian Gazette.” Sir, The caracol at the corner of Sharia Kaer-el-Nil, which has been absorbed by the Standard Buildings, has not been replaced, and as a resident in that quartet of Cairo I should be muchh obliged if I could obtain any information as to where the new caracol is, for at the present time I, as a permanent resident in this quarter of the town, am entirely ignorant of any caracal in the proximity to this neighborhood. As far as I know there is no caracol for many kilometres around, with the exception of the Abdin caracol. Surely this state of things ought to be remedied at once in view of the of Egypt.
Truly yours- “BOBBY.”
Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, September 23.

div.head: A Resident of Welland Finds Relief in Pe-ru-na.
div.p: Suffered 15 Years.
Mr. Ozial Rounds, Welland, Ont., a retired luraberman and a resident of Welland for half a century, writes:
“For fifteen years prior to 1900 I was a sufferer from hay asthma and chronic diarrhea. I grew weak and emaciated and was tortured with insomnia.
“I was treated by eminent physicians but, if anything, was worse than ever. In fact, I was in as miserable a condition as a man could be.

“However, I chanced to try Peruna and noticed an Improvement. Thus encouraged, I continued, and after taking several bottles of your precious Peruna, I was entirely well and a wonder to myself and friends.
“If, at my advanced age, 88 years, I have obtained such good results from Peruna, after so many years of needless efficacy in the treatment of younger persons.”

div.head: ACROSS TRIPOLI. A DARING JOURNEY.
div.p: Reuter’s Agency learns that, according to telegraphic advices, Mr. Hans Vischer, British resident at Kuka, on Lake Chad, who is making an adventurous journey across the Great Sahara, arrived at Murzuk a Turkish garrison town, in the Tripolitan hiuterland, and the capital of Fezzan, in the middle of August after a desert march of forty days from Tripoli.

Mr. Vischer and his companions, who include a number of British Moslem pilgrims who are returning from Mecca to their homes in Northern Nigeria, are in good health. Murzuk, which is 600 miles from Tripoli, has been reached without mishap, so far as is known, but the place is only about one-fourth of the total distance to be traversed. Although Mr. Vischer's plans are known to and approved: by the French and Turkish authorities, the remainder of his journey, which has not been accomplished by a European in the present generation, is an extremely hazardous one, not only on amount of the climatic conditions, but also owing to the uncontrolled tribes with whom be will come into contact.

Mr. Vischer left England in February for Tripoli, in order to make arrangements by which he might return to his post on Lake Chad by the unknown desert route through the "forbidden hinterland” of Tripoli. When the first incomplete sketch of the expedition became known some suspicion was aroused on the Continent, and the scheme, owing, perhaps, to the Resident’s name, was spoken of as a German political mission of a Pan-lslamic character. It is, of course, neither German nor political. At the same time, it is likely, if followed up by the establishment at Tripoli of a pilgrim caravan serai for returning pilgrims,to have far reaching effects among the Mohamedans of the Central Soudan, and immensely to increase British prestige among the Moslems of Northern Nigeria.

div.head: DANGERS OF PAN ISLAMISM.
div.p: NEED FOR WATCHFULNESS.

The very serious warnings addressed to the British people on this subject came none too soon. We have been living in a fool’s paradise so far as England is concerned, believing that the people of Egypt wore in some measure grateful to us for the benefits conferred on them by the British occupation. We never seem able to remember that a nation prefers bad government under its own rulers to a good administration under an alien race. The peasantry cares nothing for this. It is the educated class who stir up sedition. Their smattering of education leads them to believe that they are just as capable of governing as are the current rules set over them, and they reseat the slur on their capacity. I verily think that Mustapha Pasha Kamel and his followers would prefer a return to the corvee and the kourbash rather than that Egypt should remain under even temporary British occupation. That a very serious political agitation is in progress in Egypt is undeniable. That it is being engineered from Yildiz Kiosk is equally certain. What is also true is that the Sultan is using his utmost endeavour to stir up Islam against Christianity. A long letter appeared in the “Morning Post” of the 20th August over the signature of the joint secretary of the Pan-Islamic Society denying this statement. Sheikh Mushir Kidwai writes; —“The British Press also seem to be labouring under the idea that Turkey is secretly fanning fanaticism among Moslems. I boldly say say that nothing could be farther from the truth. The Turkish Government is over-considerate and would never like to hurt the feelings of the European Powers."

It is somewhat unfortunate that the joint secretary of the Pan-Islamic Society should date this denial, of what is a well-known fact, from Constantinople. It is also a somewhat remarkable coincidence that on the very day after the publication of this letter in the “Morning Post," an announcement should have appeared in the Turkish “Official Gazette” to tee effect that the Sheikh Mushir Hussein Kidwai of Lucknow had been granted the Third Class of the Imperial Order of the Osmanieh by the Sultan. All residents of Turkey know that one of the principal duties of the Ambassador in London is to telegraph to Yildiz summaries of any favourable or hostile articles that appear in the English Press, so that the police may take steps to prevent their circulation in the country. On the day following the publication of the sheikh’s appreciation to his Majesty a letter was published in the “Times” from Canon MacColl in which that learned divine denied the Sultan's claim to the Caliphate. That paper was swept out of the various hotels and restaurants. The eulogistic “Morning Post" remains to be read.

To say that the Turkish Government is over-considerate and would never like to hurt the feelings of the European Powers is ridiculous. Has the sheikh never heard of Batak and the Bulgarian massacres of thirty year ago! Or of Sassaron and the Armenian massacres of 1895? Has he forgotten that no sooner had the Sultan signed the Iradeh granting the Armenian reforms at the demand of the Powers than emissaries were sent throughout the length and breadth of Asia Minor with orders to exterminate the Armenians? Was the impertinent advance to Tabah, towards which the Sultan can lay no claim, a considerate act towards a Power which has twice saved Turkey from her hereditary foe Russia. There are innumerable minor matters which show that the Turkish Government never omits a chance of showing her contempt for Christian nations. It is not so long since that the Governor General of Bayrout displayed such a hostile attitude to the American Consul that his recall was demanded by the President. The Sultan refused to throw his favourite overboard. The American fleet appeared off the port, and the Pasha was removed, only to be promoted to a more valuable province. Recently on the murder of the Prefect of Constantinople Rerchid Praha was nominated to that important post, where he will have every opportunity of adding to his enormous fortune. If we except Germany, the present Sultan seems to take a delight in sanctioning acts which he must know will cause annoyance to the European Powers. It is enough fur an official to have been reported by a foreign Ambassador for venality or for a worse crime. Abu-ul-Hamid is then sure to promote the culprit.

Izzet Pacha, the second secretary at the Palace, a few years ago held the position of Judge of the Mixed Tribunal at Stamboul. His conduct became so scandalous that the French and English Ambassadors demanded his dismissal, and in such forcible terms that the Sultan was compelled to secede. In a few weeks he was made secretary to his Majesty and since then has become the most important man in the Empire. He it is who directs the Pan-Islamic campaign, which is, of coarse, mainly directed against England and France, two countries which Isset Pacha can never forgive. It was Isset who organised and carried through the Armenian massacres of 1896, and who suggested the despatch of select preachers to Afghanistan and Central Asia to stir up a holy war after the successful campaign against Greece. To the notion of these priests we owe the ferment on the Indian frontier which led to the Tirsh campaign in 1898. It is he who initiated the Hedjez Railway, and emulated through the length and breadth of lotto appeals for money for this so called religion, undertaking. It is through his advice that the Sultan has taken Indian Moslems into his own personal service at Yildez Kiosk, and through their influence it is that the Pan-Islamic propaganda is being so actively pushed in India, so that we have the spectacle of the secretary of the London branch of the Pan-Islamic Society instructing the English on the doctrines of his school from Constantinople.

In spite of the opinion of Canon Malcolm MacColl I am constrained to admit that the Sultan is looked upon as Khalifa of Islam by the Moslems of India, and is prayed for by name in every mosque that is under the Sunni sect, throughout the world. Under these circumstances a Pan-Islamic campaign may have very far-reaching effects for us, and our states- men should take energetic steps to counteract the evil. We must fight calumny by troth. To the Sultan’s assertion that we are the enemies of Islam we must maintain that we are not fighting Islam, but Hamidianism, which is opposed to the spirit of Islam. We should wage an active campaign to oppose the one that the Sultan is carrying on against us in Egypt and in India. We should point out the freedom that exists in India and in Egypt, and compare it with the tyranny and deipotism which reigns in the Ottoman Empire. In India and in Egypt every man is free to travel as he pleases, all servants of the State are regularly paid, justice is beyond suspicion. In Turkey no man can leave his village with-out a passport, and in the case of Government servants even the Minister of Police is unable to give a “permit de voyage” without an Imperial Iradeh. No Government servant, unless indeed he enjoys Palace protection, ever receives more than six months' pay in the year. His pay drafts for the remaining six are discounted by Cabinet Ministers at the rate of 2s. in the pound, so that few officials draw more than seven months' pay per annum, the State pays the full salary, and the Cabinet Ministers batten on their subordinates. Promotion is dependent entirely on Palace favouritism. The son of a Minister is made a General of Division or a member of The Council of State with a large and regularly- paid salary at the age of thirty. A man with- out protection may remain a subaltern or a subordinate on a salary of two or three pounds a month for the whole of his life. I know admirals who have reached that rank before they were thirty, and who have never kept a watch or been out of sight of land. There are generals of division who have never left Constantinople or done a day's duty with a regiment. There are "Conseillers Legistes” at the Sublime Porte (sons of Palace favourites) who never go near their offices except to draw their pay, and who are as ignorant of law as they are of the binomial theorem. Not long since a vacancy occurred in the post of Ottoman representative on the committee of the Tobacco Regie (a foreign society). This required a man of education and experience. An ex Grand Vizier applied for it for his sop, a youth of twenty-five. of no education and no experience. The Sultan, however, in this instance, chose a good man, but the Grand Vizier's son, who is not a lawyer, was made a Conseiller Legiste on a salary of £150 a month! The Minister of Mines and Forests is an individual who was dismissed from the “Dette Poblique” for dishonesty. His brother has been twice imprisoned for fraud, yet he is Under Secretary of State for Public Works. Cases like these exist without number. In fact, the state of affairs in Turkey is not merely a disgrace to Europe, but also to Islam. Were one tithe of it known to the many honest well-educated Muslims who are loyal servants of the British Government in India and in Egypt the Pan-Islamic campaign of Abd-ul-Hamid would die a natural death.

Unfortunately we allow men like Mustapha Pasha Kamel to scatter their lies broadcast through Egypt, and make no effort by means of a well directed Government organ to disseminate the real truth- That these Pan-Islamic journals are subsidised by the Sultan is undeniable I have never visited the Palcoe without having seen a copy of the "El Lawa” or some similar scurrilous Arabic paper on the table of the Chamberlain's room. And this has to my knowledge been going on for the last twenty years. It is true that the Sultan has some sense of complaint against us in that we allow political refugees from Turkey to take up their abode in Egypt, and from there to publish more or less revolutionary attacks on him. Admiral Faik Pasha, who was for many years the Chief of the Staff of the Ottoman Navy, Ahmed Jellsludin Pasha, and many others who have fled from Turkish misrule, are comfortably installed on the backs of the Nile. In the ease of Ahmed Jellsludin, who was for many years the chief of Abd-ul-Hamid's secret police, I should not be surprised to learn that he was an active member of the Pan Islamic Committee, although Yildis pretends that he is a political refugee.

Pan-Islamism is a lever that we can work as well at the Sultan. It is true that he is looked on as the Khalifa by the Muslims in India and in Egypt, by upwards of ninety millions of King Edward's subjects, but he has committed acts which are against the Sacred Law of Islam. He has tampered with the Sacred Books, and so long ago as the year 1890 there was a strong movement to declare him incapable of reigning in consequence of his conduct towards Islam. It is a well known fact that overtures were made to Lord Carrie when he was Ambassador that Abd-ul-Hamid should be deposed and replaced by his brother the actual Sultan Murad. Lord Carrie refused to listen to the conspirators, but it is now well known that the garrison at Yildiz had been won over as well as the then Sheikh ul islam, and that the powerful secretary Izzet Pasha was willing to assist in the dethronement of Abd-ul-Hamid. What was feasible in 1895 is far more so now, when the whole country cries out against the rapacity and maladministration of Yildis. (Constantinople Correspondent “Birmingham Daily Post.”)

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: (From our own Correspondent.)
London, September 13.

The 3rd Bettalion Coldstream Guards, numbering about 850 officers, non-commissioned officers and men, under the command of Brevet Colonel G. R P. Smith, with Brevet Lieutenant Colonel J. A. G. Richardson-Drummond-Hay second in command, will embark on the S.S. Sicilia at Southampton on the 39th inst. for Alexandria. The troopship will also convey the various drafts for the regiments serving in Egypt. The Coldstreamers on arrival at Alexandria about the 11th October, will proceed to Cairo, where they will remain until they return home to be reduced. The exact date of disbandment has not yet been finally decided. The other officers of the battalion are Majors C. S. 0. Monck, Earl of Lanesborough, and C.E. Pereira ; Captains H.F. Stirling. G. A. 0. Lane, Hon. C.H.S. Monck, W. H. V. Darell ; Lieutenants W. M. Beckwith, R. B. J. Smith, G. M. Paget, J.H.J. Phillips, Sir W. Bartelott, W. A. Fuller-Maitland, S. J. Burton, H. D. Bentinck; Second Lientenant R. A. Arkwright, W. St. A WardeAldam, A. G. Soames, E. D. H. Tollemache, G. A. Campbell; Lieutenant and Adjut. and J. R Gibbs, Quarter master and Lieutenant W. Johnson and Surgeon Lieutenant Colonel J. F. Bateson.
Second Lieutenant A. W. Molony 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, has been placed on duty with the draft which the Battalion is preparing to join the 1st Battalion at Alexandria.

Major General Lawrence W. Parsons, C.B., Inspector of Royal Artillery in India, has been selected for the command of the Eighth Division at Cork, in succession to Major General Sir William G. Knox, E.C.B., who has commanded the Division since the resignation of Sir Reginald Pole Carew, K.C.B., Major General Parsons commaded a brigade of Royal Artillery in the fighting for the relief of Ladysmith, and was present at the battles of Colenso, Spion Kop, Vaal Kran’z, Tugela Heights, and Peter’s Hill; the operations in Natal, and as a staff officer saw further service in operations in ' the Transvaal, including the action of Belfast, Lydenburg, &c., &c. (mentioned three times in despatches, C.B., Queen's medal with six clasps).

It is stated that the Dapot of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, which has been stationed at Omagh, Co. Tyrone, since 1883, will be transferred shortly to Enniskillen, where the Inniskillings were formed in 1688. The barracks at Omagh would then be used accommodate detachment from the battalion stationed at Londonderry.

It has been decided by the Army Council that the wearing of side arms by all ranks below Staff Serjeants in the Royal Army Medical Corps (Regular, Militia and Volunteer) is to be discontinued. The side arms are to be returned to the Army Ordnance Department.

Some artillerists are of opinion that the 12 inch guns of the Dreadnought are scarcely large enough for battleships of that tonnage and Power. The maximum length for handiness in working seems to have been reached, but a larger calibre could be given to the 50 ton gun-say 13.5.

The battleship Formidable, Captain Ernest A. Simons, is on the voyage home from the Mediterranean Station to pay off at Portsmouth, where she will be re commissioned for another tour of service in the same waters.

L‘Administration des Chemins de Fer de l’Etat a l'honneur d'informer la Public qu’il sera procédé le Samedi, 29 Septembre courant, á neuf heures du matin, suivant Kaimet-Mazad, á la sects aux ecnchéres publiques, aux Magasins Géuéraux de Boulac (Caire) d’une qiantité de vieux bois et vieilies traverses déposée au Magasin de Boulac No. 1, de vieux meubles de bureau déposés aux Magasins Généraux de Boulac ainsi que d’une quantité de vieilies portes et features existent au District du Caire, (Voie). La nomenclature des dita articles ainsi que les conditiones de la vente se trouvent aux Magasins Généraux de Boulac cu on peut eu prendre connaissance, cheque jour, de neuf heures du matin á une heure p.m., sauf les dimanches et jours fédiés.

Pour etre admis á concourir, le soumissionnaire devra verser, au préalable, L.E. 10 (dix Livres Egyptienne-) á titre de dépot provisoire. Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu’a concurrence du 10% (dix pour cent) du montant de l’oftre agréée, et enlévera a ses frais les lots qui lui seront adjugés dans an délai de treute jours a compter de la date de l’avis d'acceptation de son offre, les dimanches et jours fériés non compris.
Toute offre faite ou déposée postérieurement an jour et a l’heure ci 'essus ne sera pas prise en considération.
L'Administration ne s'engage pas a accepter les prix les plus élevés ni n’importe quelle offre. Esle se réserve le droit de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le 22 Septembre 1906 28553-2 2

div.head: Notice.
div.p: SUDAN GOVERNMENT
DISPOSAL OP BUILDING SITES AT PORT SUDAN
The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Lessehold held at Annual Rents on Building Lesse for Eigbty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will be payable only from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rents fixed in default of Agreement by Arbitration at the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the value of Buildings erected by Lessees will Not be regarded as a ground for Increase of Rent.

Example : If a plot is leased for a term of 80 years from 1st January 1907 then on the expiration of that term the Lessee will have a right (subject to observance of his convenant etc) to obtain a fresh lease for a further period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in perpatuity. The revised rent will be calculated on the value the site, would bear if it were vacant building lands.
Offers are invited of Premiums for the Purchase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issued by the Sudan Government and most be received at Khartoum not later than 1st January 1907.

Particulars of the sites offered. Plan of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Form of Tender, specimen -Form of Lease etc. will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours.
Khartoum: ‘Office of Director of Agriculture and Lands (T)and Office of Governor of Khartoum Province.
Cairo: *Office of Sudan Agent (T).
Port Sudan : Office of Inspector (Government Office) (T)
Suakin: Office of Governor of Red Sea Province.
Wadi Halfa: Office of Governor of Halfa Province.
El Damer: Office of Governor of Berber Provinces.
Atbara: Office of Director of Railways.

Alexandria: Office of Mr. Macpherson Grant
Port Said: Office of Dixon Bey, War Office Representative.
London : *Office of Col. Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster, and the Sudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez: Office of Capt. Falconer, War Office Representative.

For the convenience of intending purchasers the Conditions of Tender and Sale have been translated into Arabic and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy at the Offices in the above list which are distinguishad by a capital T.
Further information will be obtainable after the publication of the above mentioned documents on application in writing to The Director of Agriculture and Lands, Khartoum.
*Copies of the Documents will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T.or 1 Shilling per . copy at the Offices marked with an asterisk.

div.head: Sudan Government, NOTICE.
div.p: Persons importing Egyptian labourers to work in the Sudan are recommenced to entre into a written contract with them.This contract should be explained and signed by the Labourers in presence of an official or other reliable witness. 28283A 30-10-906

div.head: GOUVERNEMENT DU SOUDAN Concessions de Terrains a Batir a Port-Soudan
div.p: AVIS
Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochaine ment disposer, par voie d'-djudication d’eu viron 400 parcelles de terrains a batir à Port- Soudan.

Les dites parcelles seront données à bail emphytéotique, pour une dorés de 80 années au partir du ler Jauvier 1907, moyennant loyes annuel, a charge pour le locataire de batir. La loyer ne sera payable qu’à partir de la date de l’acceptation de l’oftre.
Les baux seront renouvelables a perpétuités, moyennant un loyer variable filé a la fin di chique terme, soit d’accord, soit par arbitrage.
Eu fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des batirments élevés par le locataire ne sera pau considérée comme un motif d’angmentation de loyer.

EXEMPLE: Si une parcelle de terrain est louée pour une dorée de 80 années a partir du 1er Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, a l’expiration des es délai, le locataire aura un droit (A condition d’observar les conditions du bail) d’obtenir no nouyean bail pour one nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyal modifié, et ainsi de saits a perpétuité.
Le loyer modifié sera calcu;é aur la valeur du terrain, s'il était libre de construction

Des offres sont demandées pour les baux emphytéotiqus dont s'agit ; osa offres devront mentionner 1a prime que le soumissionnaire est disposé A payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chaoun des lots. La dite prime devra être payée en un seul versement a la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offres doivent être faites par sonmission, sur les formules dressées par le Gouvernement du Soudan, et doivant être reçues a Khartoum avant le 1er Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains oflarta, le plan delà ville, les conditions de l’adjod oation et de la ounoesrion, la formn’e de soumission, spér fi oa- tion do bail, sere .t A ta disposition do Public A partir do 1er Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci- après indiqué*, dorant les heures de bureau.
